page.title: 02ECOLOGY CONTINUED
page.content: WAS MAINLY MOSSES AND LEAF LITTER. UNDER THE CANOPY OF AN OLD BEECH TREE, WHICH COVERED AN AREA OF ABOUT THREE HUNDRED SQUARE METRES, WE FOUND THAT SUNLIGHT WAS ABLE TO PENETRATE DOWN THROUGH THE BRANCHES AS SHORT GRASSES, MOSSES AND WOOD SORREL WERE ABLE TO GROW. SOME HONEYSUCKLE WAS ALSO GROWING ALONG THE EDGE OF THE CANOPY. AMONG THE SOFT SPONGEY LAYERS OF BEECH MAST AND LEAF LITTER WERE DIFFERENT FUNGI SHOWING THAT IT WAS DAMP. SPIDERS, ANTS AND WOODLICE WERE SEEN UNDER DEAD BARK. UNDER AN OAK TREE CANOPY WERE OAK SAPLINGS, BRAMBLES AND ELDER ABOUT ONE METRE HIGH, TOGETHER WITH NETTLES FOXGLOVES AND GRASSES. ON THE GROUND WERE DEAD LEAVES AND ACORNS, TWIGS AND RABBIT DROPPINGS. EVIDENCE OF MAN IN THIS PART PART OF THE WOOD WAS SHOTGUN CARTRIDGES AND TRUCK TRACKS.
